form.official-title: To establish the Surface Transportation Board as an independent establishment, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Surface Transportation Board Reauthorization Act of 2014.

section.header: References to title 49, United States Code

section.header: Establishment of Surface Transportation Board as an independent establishment

subsection.text: Section 701(a) is amended to read as follows:
The Surface Transportation Board is an independent establishment of the United States Government.

paragraph.text: Section 703 is amended—

by redesignating subsections (b), (d), and (e) as subsections (a), (b), and (c), respectively; and
by adding at the end the following:

subsection.text: Whenever the Board submits or transmits any budget estimate, budget request, supplemental budget estimate, or other budget information, legislative recommendation, prepared testimony for a congressional hearing, or comment on legislation to the President or to the Office of Management and Budget, it shall concurrently transmit a copy thereof to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation of the Senate and the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure of the House of Representatives. No officer or agency of the United States shall have any authority to require the Board to submit its budget estimates or requests, legislative recommendations, prepared testimony for congressional hearings, or comments on legislation to any officer or agency of the United States for approval, comments, or review, prior to the submission of the recommendations, testimony, or comments to Congress.

section.text: Section 703(a), as redesignated by section 3 of this Act, is amended to read as follows:

paragraph.text: The Board shall be deemed to be an agency for purposes of section 552b of title 5.

subparagraph.text: Notwithstanding section 552b of title 5, a majority of the members may hold a meeting that is not open to public observation to discuss official agency business if—

clause.text: no vote or other disposition of official agency business is taken at the meeting;
each individual present at the meeting is a member or an employee of the Board; and
the General Counsel of the Board is present at the meeting.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided under subparagraph (C), not later than 2 business days after the conclusion of a meeting under subparagraph (A), the Board shall make available to the public, in a place easily accessible to the public—

clause.text: a list of the individuals present at the meeting; and
a summary of the matters discussed at the meeting, except for any matters the Board properly determines may be withheld from the public under section 552b(c) of title 5.

subparagraph.text: If a discussion under subparagraph (A) relates, directly or indirectly, to an ongoing proceeding before the Board, the Board shall make the disclosure under subparagraph (B) on the date of the final Board decision.

subparagraph.header: Preservation of open meetings requirements for agency action
subparagraph.text: Nothing in this paragraph shall limit the applicability of section 552b of title 5 with respect to a meeting of the members other than that described in this paragraph.
Nothing in this paragraph—

clause.text: shall limit the applicability of section 552b of title 5 with respect to any information which is proposed to be withheld from the public under subparagraph (B)(ii); and
authorizes the Board to withhold from any individual any record that is accessible to that individual under section 552a of title 5, United States Code.

subsection.text: Section 11701(a) is amended by striking only on complaint and inserting on the Board's own initiative or on complaint.

Section 10704(b) is amended by striking the first sentence and inserting The Board may begin a proceeding under subsection (a)(1) on its own initiative or upon complaint, except that a proceeding to determine the reasonableness of the level of a rate charged by a carrier may only be initiated upon complaint..

Section 704 is amended by striking on its activities. and inserting on its activities, including each instance in which the Board has initiated an investigation on its own initiative under this chapter or subtitle IV..
Section 10701(d)(3) is amended to read as follows:

paragraph.text: The Board shall maintain a simplified and expedited method for determining the reasonableness of challenged rates in those cases in which a full stand-alone cost presentation is too costly, given the value of the case.

subsection.text: Section 10704(d) is amended by striking the first sentence and inserting The Board shall maintain procedures to ensure expeditious handling of challenges to the reasonableness of railroad rates..

section.text: Section 10704(d), as amended by section 7 of this Act, is further amended—

paragraph.text: by striking (d) The and inserting (d)(1) The; and
by adding at the end the following:

subparagraph.text: Except as provided under subparagraph (B), in a stand-alone cost rate challenge, the Board shall comply with the following timeline:

clause.text: For discovery, completion not later than 150 days after the date that the challenge is initiated.
For development of the evidentiary record, completion not later than 155 days after the date that discovery is complete under clause (i).
For submission of a closing brief, submission not later than 60 days after the date that development of the evidentiary record is complete under clause (ii).
For a final Board decision, issuance not later than 180 days after the date that the last closing brief is submitted under clause (iii).

subparagraph.text: The Board may extend a timeline under subparagraph (A) after a request from any party or in the interest of due process.

section.text: Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Surface Transportation Board shall initiate an ex parte proceeding on whether contract proposals for multiple origin-to-destination movements have adversely impacted the intent of Congress that the Surface Transportation Board’s rate challenge procedures remain available to shippers that are subject to railroad market dominance, and how the Board can prevent such practices in the future.

Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Surface Transportation Board shall report to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation of the Senate and the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure of the House of Representatives on—

paragraph.text: whether current methodologies are sufficient to address the complexity of large rate cases; and
alternative methodologies that could streamline and expedite large rate cases.

section.header: Arbitration of certain rail rates, practices, and common carrier service expectation disputes

subsection.text: Chapter 117 is amended by adding at the end the following:

section.header: Arbitration of certain rail rates, practices, and common carrier service disputes

subsection.text: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of the Surface Transportation Board Reauthorization Act of 2014, the Board shall promulgate regulations to establish a binding arbitration process to resolve rail rate, practice, and common carrier service expectation complaints subject to the jurisdiction of the Board.
The binding arbitration process—

paragraph.text: shall apply to disputes involving rates, practices, and common carrier service expectations subject to the jurisdiction of the Board; and
shall not apply to—

subparagraph.text: disputes to obtain the grant, denial, stay, or revocation of any license, authorization, or exemption, or to prescribe for the future any conduct, rules, or results of general, industry-wide applicability, or to enforce a labor protective condition; and
disputes solely between 2 or more rail carriers.

paragraph.text: The Board—

subparagraph.text: may make the binding arbitration process available only to the relevant parties—

clause.text: after the filing of a formal complaint; or
upon petition by a party at the conclusion of any informal dispute resolution process provided by the Board for a complaint subject to this section;

subparagraph.text: with respect to rate disputes, may make the binding arbitration process available only to the relevant parties if the rail carrier has market dominance, as determined under section 10707 of this title; and
shall determine whether to pursue the binding arbitration process not later than 30 days after the date that a petition or formal complaint is filed.

paragraph.text: Initiation of the binding arbitration process shall preclude the Board from separately reviewing a complaint or dispute related to the same rail rate, practice, or common carrier service expectation in a covered dispute involving the same parties.

In resolving a covered dispute involving the reasonableness of a rail carrier's rates, the arbitrator or panel of arbitrators, as applicable, shall consider the Board's methodologies for setting maximum lawful rates, giving due consideration to the need for differential pricing to permit a rail carrier to collect adequate revenues within the meaning of section 10704(a)(2).

In resolving a dispute involving common carrier service expectations, the arbitrator or panel of arbitrators, as applicable, shall consider the rates and service terms, and any changes thereto, as published or otherwise made available under subsection (b), (c), or (d) of section 11101.

subsection.text: Any decision reached in an arbitration process under this section—

paragraph.text: shall—

subparagraph.text: be consistent with subtitle IV;
be in writing;
contain findings of fact and conclusions; and
be binding upon the parties; and

paragraph.text: shall not have any precedential effect in any other or subsequent arbitration dispute.
An arbitrator or panel of arbitrators shall be selected not later than 14 days after the date of the Board's decision to initiate arbitration.

The evidentiary process of the binding arbitration process shall be completed not later than 90 days after the date that the arbitration process is initiated, unless a party requests an extension and the arbitrator or panel of arbitrators, as applicable, grants it.
The arbitrator or panel of arbitrators, as applicable, shall issue a decision not later than 30 days after the date that the evidentiary record is closed.
The Board may extend any of the timelines in this subsection upon the agreement of all parties in the dispute.

Arbitration under this section shall be conducted by an arbitrator, or a panel of arbitrators, selected from a roster, maintained by the Board, of persons with rail transportation, economic regulation, professional or business experience, including agriculture, in the private sector.

subparagraph.text: If the parties cannot mutually agree on an arbitrator, or the lead arbitrator of a panel of arbitrators, the parties shall select the arbitrator or lead arbitrator from the roster by alternately striking names from the roster until only 1 name remains.
For purposes of this section, a panel of arbitrators shall be selected as follows:

clause.text: Notwithstanding subparagraph (A), each party to a dispute shall select 1 arbitrator from the roster.
The parties to a dispute may mutually select 1 arbitrator from the roster to serve as the lead arbitrator of the panel of arbitrators.

paragraph.text: The parties shall share the costs of the arbitration equally.

subsection.text: An arbitral decision under this section may award the payment of damages or rate prescriptive relief, but the value of the award shall be limited as follows:

paragraph.text: For common carrier service and practice disputes, the damage award may not exceed $2,000,000.

For rate disputes, the damage award, including any rate prescription, may not exceed $25,000,000, and any rate prescription shall be limited to not longer than 5 years from the date of the arbitral decision.

subsection.text: If a party appeals a decision under this section to the Board, the Board may review the decision under this section to determine if—

paragraph.text: the decision is consistent with subtitle IV as applied by the Board; or
the award limitation under subsection (g).

section.header: Compilation of complaints at Surface Transportation Board

subsection.text: Section 704, as amended by section 6 of this Act, is further amended—

paragraph.text: by striking the section heading and inserting the following:
by inserting (a) Annual report.— before The Board and indenting appropriately; and
by adding at the end the following:
The Board shall establish and maintain a database of complaints received by the Board.
The Board shall post a quarterly report of formal and informal service complaints received by the Board during the previous quarter that includes—

subparagraph.text: a list of the type of each complaint;
the geographic region of each complaint; and
the resolution of each complaint, if appropriate.

paragraph.text: The quarterly report may identify a complainant that submitted an informal complaint only upon the written consent of the complainant.
Each quarterly report shall be posted on the Board's public website.

subsection.text: The table of contents for chapter 7 is amended by striking the item relating to section 704 and inserting the following:

section.text: Not later than 60 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Surface Transportation Board shall begin providing quarterly reports to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation of the Senate and the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure of the House of Representatives on the Surface Transportation Board's progress toward addressing the issues raised in each unfinished regulatory proceeding, regardless of whether the proceeding is subject to a statutory or regulatory deadline.
It is the sense of Congress that—

paragraph.text: the Surface Transportation Board should review the methodology employed to define the business cycle in its annual determination of revenue adequacy and consider undertaking, if necessary, a rulemaking to define the business cycle;

as part of Docket No. EP 711, the Surface Transportation Board should consider if a rulemaking proceeding on mandatory competitive switching is needed to ensure a viable competitive national rail system; and

if the Surface Transportation Board determines a rulemaking proceeding on mandatory competitive switching is needed, the Surface Transportation Board should ensure that such rulemaking is completed in as timely a manner as possible.

subparagraph.text: by redesignating section 727 as section 728; and

subsection.text: The Inspector General of the Department of Transportation, in accordance with the mission of the Inspector General to prevent and detect fraud and abuse, shall have authority to review only the financial management, property management, and business operations of the Surface Transportation Board, including internal accounting and administrative control systems, to determine compliance with applicable Federal laws, rules, and regulations.
In carrying out this section, the Inspector General shall—

paragraph.text: keep the Chairman of the Board and the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation of the Senate and the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure of the House of Representatives fully and currently informed about problems relating to administration of the internal accounting and administrative control systems of the Board;
issue findings and recommendations for actions to address such problems; and

report periodically to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation of the Senate and the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure of the House of Representatives on any progress made in implementing actions to address such problems.

subsection.text: In carrying out this section, the Inspector General may exercise authorities granted to the Inspector General under subsections (a) and (b) of section 6 of the Inspector General Act of 1978 (5 U.S.C. App.).

paragraph.text: There are authorized to be appropriated to the Secretary of Transportation for use by the Inspector General of the Department of Transportation such sums as may be necessary to cover expenses associated with activities pursuant to the authority exercised under this section.
In the absence of an appropriation under this subsection for an expense referred to in paragraph (1), the Inspector General and the Board shall have a reimbursable agreement to cover such expense.

subsection.text: Chapter 117 is amended by adding at the end the following:

section.header: Voluntary arbitration of certain rail rates, practices, and common carrier service disputes

subsection.text: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of the Surface Transportation Board Reauthorization Act of 2014, the Board shall promulgate regulations to establish a voluntary, but binding, arbitration process to resolve rail rate, practice, and common carrier service expectation complaints subject to the jurisdiction of the Board.
The binding arbitration process—

paragraph.text: shall not apply to—

subparagraph.text: disputes to obtain the grant, denial, stay, or revocation of any license, authorization, or exemption, or to prescribe for the future any conduct, rules, or results of general, industry-wide applicability, or to enforce a labor protective condition; and
disputes solely between 2 or more rail carriers; and

paragraph.text: shall not prevent parties from independently seeking or utilizing private arbitration services to resolve any disputes they may have.
The Board—

subparagraph.text: may make the voluntary, but binding, arbitration process available only to the relevant parties—

clause.text: after the filing of a formal complaint;
upon petition by all parties at the conclusion of any informal dispute resolution process provided by the Board for a complaint subject to this section; or
through current or future procedures adopted by the Board to facilitate voluntary, but binding, arbitration;

subparagraph.text: with respect to rate disputes, may make the binding arbitration process available only to the relevant parties if the rail carrier has market dominance, as determined under section 10707 of this title; and
shall determine whether to pursue the binding arbitration process not later than 30 days after the date that a petition or formal complaint is filed.

paragraph.text: Initiation of the binding arbitration process shall preclude the Board from separately reviewing a complaint or dispute related to the same rail rate, practice, or common carrier service expectation in a covered dispute involving the same parties.

In resolving a covered dispute involving the reasonableness of a rail carrier's rates, the arbitrator or panel of arbitrators, as applicable, shall consider the Board's methodologies for setting maximum lawful rates, giving due consideration to the need for differential pricing to permit a rail carrier to collect adequate revenues within the meaning of section 10704(a)(2).

In resolving a dispute involving common carrier service expectations, the arbitrator or panel of arbitrators, as applicable, shall consider the rates and service terms, and any changes thereto, as published or otherwise made available under subsection (b), (c), or (d) of section 11101.

subsection.text: Any decision reached in an arbitration process under this section—

paragraph.text: shall—

subparagraph.text: be in writing;
contain findings of fact and conclusions; and
be binding upon the parties; and

paragraph.text: shall not have any precedential effect in any other or subsequent arbitration dispute.
An arbitrator or panel of arbitrators shall be selected not later than 14 days after the date of the Board's decision to initiate arbitration.

The evidentiary process of the binding arbitration process shall be completed not later than 90 days after the date that the arbitration process is initiated, unless a party requests an extension and the arbitrator or panel of arbitrators, as applicable, grants it.
The arbitrator or panel of arbitrators, as applicable, shall issue a decision not later than 30 days after the date that the evidentiary record is closed.
The Board may extend any of the timelines in this subsection upon the agreement of all parties in the dispute.

Unless otherwise agreed by all of the parties, an arbitration under this section shall be conducted by a panel of arbitrators, selected from a roster, maintained by the Board, of persons with rail transportation, economic regulation, professional or business experience, including agriculture, in the private sector.

subparagraph.text: If the parties cannot mutually agree on an arbitrator, or the lead arbitrator of a panel of arbitrators, the parties shall select the arbitrator or lead arbitrator from the roster by alternately striking names from the roster until only 1 name remains.
For purposes of this section, a panel of arbitrators shall be selected as follows:

clause.text: The parties to a dispute may mutually select 1 arbitrator from the roster to serve as the lead arbitrator of the panel of arbitrators.
If the parties cannot mutually agree on a lead arbitrator, the parties shall select a lead arbitrator using the process described in subparagraph (A).
In addition to the lead arbitrator selected under this subparagraph, each party to a dispute shall select 1 additional arbitrator from the roster.

paragraph.text: The parties shall share the costs of the arbitration equally.

subsection.text: An arbitral decision under this section may award the payment of damages or rate prescriptive relief, but the value of the award shall be limited as follows:

paragraph.text: For common carrier service and practice disputes, the damage award may not exceed $2,000,000.

For rate disputes, the damage award, including any rate prescription, may not exceed $25,000,000, and any rate prescription shall be limited to not longer than 5 years from the date of the arbitral decision.

subsection.text: If a party appeals a decision under this section to the Board, the Board may review the decision under this section to determine if—

paragraph.text: a clear abuse of arbitral authority or discretion occurred;
the decision directly contravenes statutory authority; or
the award limitation under subsection (g) was violated.
